title: Does the existence of the Universe make sense without intelligent beings there to observe it and question it? - Quora

response.answer_text: The way I see it, why does it need to make sense? The universe is and therefore it exists. Or does it? What proof do we actually have? Look to the sky at night and supposedly you are staring out into the universe. Full of stars, other galaxies and other planets. What physical proof do we actually have though? You can’t touch it. You can’t go see anything out there for yourself. What if everything that you have been told is based on a giant misconception? I know there are observatories with massive telescopes that peer out into the darkness and let us see what may exist. How about a completely different perspective on intelligence and the universe? What if earth is like being in an aquarium? You can see out if you look but you can’t reach any farther than your boundaries or limitations allow you to. We have been told about things like landing on the moon, the Mars Rovers and even the Galileo looking at Jupiter. Are any of those real? Yes? How do you know? Because you have been told? We are told that man is intelligent. If man is so intelligent then why do we have nothing but mass confusion everywhere we go? Man can’t even duplicate one pyramid or even the Coral Castle in Florida. What if everything you think you know about life, our planet, the solar system and even the galaxie is just a dream? When you are having a dream do you know anything else about life? Do you question what’s happening while you are there? It does sense at the time. Man is like a single leaf on a tree in the middle of the forest. Insignificant and part of a greater collective that one day will wither and die, like the leaf in fall.

Hi jamie, i feel life and existence only make sense by and through eternal creation. We could use words like ‘heaven’ and ‘god’, but these often cause offence. Words often carry prejudices with them. I believe you exist and this question is both profound and intelligent. So, this universe is special because it contains intelligent life. Is there any need for other universes? Only if certain possibilites cannot happen here. I went to the trouble of designing experiments to show we needed to find a more general quantum physics which would allow more possibilites. After many years i discovered one using only water. There is no need for other universes, everything can happen here, eventually. Perhaps the sense is where intelligent sentient is going instead of the now. One thing life has definitely taught me is patience. Sense is tomorrow.

The fact that the universe exists is independent on the capacity of those who inhabit it to perceive it. Let's suppose that we humans are the only inteligent forms of life in the universe (which I hope is not true). Before the humans evolved from to our elder relative with the chimps to who we are now, a moment in wich we weren't able to process a concept like existence; or even before there was any life on Earth, the universe was of course, still there. But still, many people have questioned the fact that things have actually happened beyond our measures of perception. There is a phrase that says: “If a tree falls down in the middle of a forest with no man to hear it brake and hit the ground, has it actually happened?” So, to your question: yes, the existence of the universe makes sense even without anyone to perceive it but of course it is on you to take a position about it and think whatever you want, even something (in my opinion) as ridiculous as that our measures of perception set limits to that which happens in this universe.

Does the existence of the Universe make sense without intelligent beings there to observe it and question it? Is there such a thing as “sense” without intelligent beings? Isn’t “sense” a cultural invention used to apply to a state of affairs that is explicable? Would the universe be explicable if there was no one to explain it nor anyone to understand the explanation? In the sense that there is no sense without human culture then the existence of the Universe would indeed make no sense without us. On the other hand if you are asking if the universe incorporates some intrinsic necessity to be understood then I’d say that’s a misguided question asking for a wild assed guess. Indeed, it is an invitation to an anthropocentric projection. If you happen to be enmeshed in some theological view that is legitimised by such a thing being true then you are likely to be misled into thinking it’s a valid and pointed question. But it isn’t. It’s like asking if trees are envious of dancers. Anthropocentric bias is difficult to avoid and it’s responsible for a shit-ton of profound absurdity.

First we would need to define “inteligent beings” and I am not sure humans at this point of our evolution could be called that collectively. That being said in my Ayahuasca Experiences I have made contact with “ancient collective presences” which view us as child like. I would answer your question as no it would not make “sense” in our terms “if” humans were the only intelligent beings in the Universe. One of the core principles of Quantum Physics is the idea that reality ( the photons that produce the light-illusion we all occupy ) exists in infinite possible states until we observe it and thus collapse all potential versions of reality into the one single option we’ve chosen to live inside. It sounds radical, I know, but there’s science to back it up. And the implications, once you truly start to consider them are limitless

This question has been taken seriously by great thinkers, but essentially it boils down to this: We are medium sized hairless apes on a tiny planet in a mid-sized galaxy in the middle of nowhere. What philosophy can we dream up that would make us the most important thing in the universe? Though we’re very creative, the fact is the universe seems to have been running smoothly for most of its lifetime without humanity to motivate it by appreciatively observing, and in due course it's quite certain it will have to carry on without us. So yes, the universe would seem to make sense with or without us or any other intelligent observer, given that the elements necessary to build any intelligent beings had to be synthesized first, and that there is no evidence that the absence of the only intelligent observer we know anything about crippled it much.

It’s a ranking that we developed to classifie people.Intelligence is only determined by human perspective. We could be totally wrong about the universe, because our sense can’t see the right things.There is no such thing as sense. It’s only a noun that we use to secure ourselves.This question isn’t really pertinent if you understand the basics of physics and philosophy. We humans are not in the center of the universe but part of it… sorry for my english, it’s not my native language. Have a great day

The universe doesn’t make sense period. Why would it? Well it makes sense in the way that it adheres to the laws of physics etc. but I have a feeling that's not what you mean. Imagine what a symphony played by a full orchestra would sound like to someone who has never heard a single note of music. It would be chaos, a cachophony of noise. the violins shrieking, the trumpets blaring it would certainly not make any sense to them. In this universe a complex symphony of high end physics, chemistry and other sciences plays on while you and me or the “average person” are the ones who have never heard music before. But to those maestros with the PhDs pushing the envelope, the universe is at least beginning to make sense.

There wouldn't be any beings around to decide that it makes sense. It doesn't seem worth bothering to get too worked up by that point though, as this seems quite a bit deeper than it actually is. Essentially, this observation is a variant of the weak anthropomorphic principle, which is the realization that without a universe where our existence was possible, we wouldn't be here to contemplate it. The weak anthropomorphic principle itself also seems rather more profound than it really is: without the precursors necessary for any specific kind of thing to exist, there would be no such things.

There is no imperative for the Universe to “be” anything other than what it is Any name or meaning, like sense, we give to the Universe is totally subjective and while it does require a sentinent being to be present to make the judgement of “sense”, said judgment does not affect the operation of the laws of physics under which the Universe operates Humans here or not the laws of physics would operate exactly the same Our perception (sense) of the Universe or not does not change the physics or its “being” therefore I would contend if “sense” of the Universe is unable to “make” changes to the Universe the Universe is immune to sense and the question has no relevance

More solipsistic-based nonsense. The universe neither knows nor cares if anything can observe it. It has to have existed for billions of years before it was even possible for anything living to exist. People who ask these questions need to put down the philosophy books and pick up a basic manual on astrophysics. For billions of years, there was nothing in the universe more complex than a hydrogen or lithium atom. Nothing. No planets, no stars, no complex elements. Nothing but the “primordial hydrogen”. It was only after this primordial hydrogen gradually formed the first stars, the “first generation” stars, and these stars “cooked” (by fusion) more complex elements and then blew those elements into the void at the end of their lifespans that more complex solar systems with rocky planets even became possible. As a biologist observed…. “If we create the universe with our minds, what did the universe look like when there was nothing more complex than a sea-slug?”

Due to the literal definition of ‘sense’, it wouldn’t make any sense at all because there would be nobody to make sense out of it. However, the same rules that control and shape the universe right now would still apply and function without any difference; just as they have for thrice as long as our solar system has even existed at all. Imagine for a second if the Earth was the only place with any type of life in the entire universe and it got suddenly wiped out. Well, in the greater scheme of things, nothing would have changed.

The question itself doesn't make sense. The existence of the universe doesn't have to ‘make sense’ it either exists or it does not. By adding ‘make sense’ to the equation you are adding comprehension as a necessary qualifier for existence and then asking if a comprehender is needed to comprehend it. That is a form of begging the question; you can derive literally no coherent conclusion from this because you've snuck in a comprehender as a quality of existence without proving that existence requires comprehension of that existence.

By intelligent beings are you referring to human beings ? Who said we were intelligent ? It is quite possible compared to other civilisations if they have developed on other worlds that we represent nothing more intelligent than a start of life Amoeba. For all we know we could be so far down the food chain that any advanced civilisation actually observing the universe may consider us not even worth giving the time of day to. It is like asking if a sulphur spewing hole on the seabed should even be there spewing its sulphur if nobody is there to observe it.

I think this question has more merit than some here have given it credit for. However, I might reword it slightly to read: “Does the Universe exist in absence of an intelligent observer?” That brings up the question: “Does the Universe exist if I’m not able to observe it?”; which can be reduced to Descartes's quest for a fundamental truth. When Descartes said “Cogito ergo sum.” (“I think therefore I am.”) he was looking for a fundamental truth; a statement that could not be falsified (it’s not a statement declaring that if something can think it’s intelligent). Following upon that, if we were to take away our thought process, everything would cease to exist. I find that interesting to think about and I find that the further we delve into the physical, the closer we come to crossing into the meta-physical.
Ah, the old “if a tree falls in the forest” argument. Yes. The universe does not exist for your benefit, and did so long before there were humans.

Yes and No. Of course the universe would be just fine without intelligent beings to observe it, why would that make a difference!? On the other hand, “to make sense” isn’t a statement only about the universe, it means to be able to be understood by an intelligent being, so without someone there to say it makes sense, that wording is meaningless. That it would exist is enough.

The universe doesn’t care. It doesn’t need to make sense, as humans define it. Most of it is void. Some of it is incredibly violent, astonishingly hot, bitingly cold, or in between. Life occurs where it can. When life gets complex enough, it starts to interpret everything in its own image. That is to be expected, yet is irrelevant to the universe’s existence, by common standards.

While treading dangerously close to “blatant arrogance”, there are currently intelligent beings in the universe observing and questioning it. They live on this planet called Tellus (aka Earth). Ever heard of Homo Sapiens Sapiens? I dare say the universe would make a whole deal less sense to me if those guys weren’t around, that is certainly true.

Does the existence of the Universe make sense without intelligent beings there to observe it and question it? And it remains true of you believe it or not, in the case of science.

Could it be we know so little about it, that it amounts to zero, in comparison to everything that is actually out there? If a deaf bear shits in the woods, but there’s nobody there to smell it, has it really happened?

But in reality everything makes perfect sense , everything obeys laws of physics . Intelligent beings also obey laws of physics , they are so complex that they have illusion of consciousness (at least i call it that). So yes Universe would make sense without intelligent beings.

Of course, we can’t get our linear-thinking minds around eternity and infinite, but think we can assume such through logical deductions. Some-thing cannot come from no-thing.

A simplified version of this question is a basic in any philosophy course; “If a leaf falls in a forest, and nobody sees it, did it really fall?” My own take on this is, “of course it did. If it fell it fell.” Sir Ken Robinson offered another variation; “If a man speaks his mind in a forest, and no woman hears him, is he still wrong?”
Forget the universe for a moment. The existence of Quora does not make sense without intelligent beings to make questions and answer them. Now, is Quora a part of the universe?

Simple answer: yes. We had a few billion years of life on this planet before the advent of “intelligent beings”. And, that is only a perspective from our little part of the Universe and our little ways of looking at it.
It doesn’t matter if the Universe makes sense or even exists without intelligence to observe it because if there is no intelligent observation then the very question would never be asked!
Yes. The universe is indifferent to you. It has existed for 14 billion years. We have no evidence of conscious observers before humans.
“Does the universe make sense without someone there to make sense of it?” By definition, no. The universe doesn’t make sense of itself. The universe just is.
